ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned essential vocabulary and basic grammar structures to be able to read and translate hieroglyphs
Basic insight into hieroglyphics and a bit of Egyptian history.
I learned about the structure and formulation of hieroglyphic sentences and phrases.
Middle Egyptian sentence structure, adjectival sentences, adverbial sentences, nominal sentences, verbs (imperative, subjunctive, etc.)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A strength was getting to work out examples in class to reinforce the grammar concepts we were learning that day. A potential weakness was that there was a lot of vocabulary to learn at any given point and it was kind of overwhelming at points.

Really nice teacher that wants everyone to succeed. Lacks structure in how your ultimate grade in the class is determined by her interpretation of your grasp on the language rather than following the exact rubric of each categories' weights in the syllabus that she provided at the beginning, and the grades you got during the semester.

I thought the course was well-organized, but it could be a little too fast paced. We never fully incorporated the vocabulary we were supposed to be learning into class, and this made it hard to manage.
The course was organized in a way that balanced lecture and practice so that learning was effective.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! The professor is great and it felt very cool to be able to translate the the sentences!
Yes, if you are drawn to interesting, unique languages and are willing to put in the work to cover the wide breadth of foundational material.

If you are looking for an easy language credit, look elsewhere as there are definitely easier ones. If you are not naturally good at language, then the rules of this one are not easy to grasp and will be hard for you. Only take this course if you are sure you want to take it, as for obvious reasons it will not be as useful outside of class as other languages. Also, make sure to treat it seriously, because it can be hard to recover if you don't understand some of the building blocks. The main benefit of this course comes in the form of the teacher. While she can be harsh at times she also tries her hardest to make the class fun because the content can definitely be monotonous at times.

Yes, if this is something you are interested in. I would note that, as language classes go, this one is not easy. You don't have to speak the language, but you do need to be able to quickly pick up on concepts and apply them.
Yes, any student interested in ancient Egyptian or ancient languages in general can learn much from this course.
